column16: Description of Program
column18: Ave. # of hours of all digital programming per week
column19: Ave. # of hours per week of digital Core Programming per week
column20: Y or N to Q 11 in Digital Core Programming: At least 50% of the Core Programming had not already aired within the previous seven days

column7: DISNEY'S 1 SATURDAY MORNING (FEATURING LONG AND SHORT-FORM EDUCATIONAL ELEMENTS)
column16: This two-hour program block features three half-hour educational series in combination with several short-form educational elements. The latter includes "Great Minds...Think For Themselves" (American history segments) and "Where'd It Go?" (short segments describing animal behavior). Disney's Doug -- Narrated via the spoken journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, this series uses humor and fantasy in depicting the struggles of a twelve-year-old boy to define identity, develop self-confidence, resolve family and school problems and maintain friendships strained by preadolescent physical and emotional change. Series episodes promote values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. Disney's Pepper Ann -- "Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively. Disney's Recess -- "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

This series addresses many of the key developmental issues of middle childhood. A group of Dalmatian puppies and a resourceful chicken named "Spot" are featured in stories that center on problem-solving. Plots frequently introduce conflicts over rules, learning responsibility, attempts to gain peer acceptance, learning from mistakes and efforts to help other animals or human characters. The series encourages prosocial values such as empathy, fairness and cooperative behavior, as well as modeling information-gathering and strategic thinking. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

column7: THE NEW ADVENTURES OF WINNIE THE POOH
column16: Based on the classic Winnie The Pooh books by author A.A. Milne, "The New Adventures Of Winnie The Pooh" depicts the everyday lives of Christopher Robin and his animal companions Pooh, Piglet, Rabbit, Tigger, Eeyore, Owl and Gopher. Stories convey strong prosocial messages about honesty, taking responsibility, persistence, cooperative effort, friendship and caring. Episodes selected for the 1998-99 package present stories having greatest educational relevance to younger viewers. Many of these stories are designed to help younger children distinguish between fantasy and reality, identify feelings and overcome common childhood fears. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

Primarily designed for children in the middle school grades, "Squigglevision" uses activities at a radio station and in the courtroom as springboards for teaching scientific concepts and their everyday applications. Characters use critical thinking to examine and describe phenomena, thereby helping the home viewer to sharpen observational and sequential thinking skills. They demonstrate both inductive and deductive reasoning and evaluate hypotheses in light of data obtained and make judgments. Scientific and math estimation concepts are illustrated by means of practical "demonstrations" and graphics. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

This short-form educational program teaches concepts in grammar, math, U.S. history, science and finance by transforming these concepts into popular song, rhyme and amusing visuals. This method of presenting academic concepts has proven to be a powerful instructional tool.

This short-form educational program teaches concepts in grammar, math, U.S. history, science and finance by transforming these concepts into popular song, rhyme and amusing visuals. This method of presenting academic concepts has proven to be a powerful instructional tool.

column7: ABC KIDS MOVIE MATINEE: DISNEY'S ONE SATURDAY MORNING CRUSH MARATHON
column16: Selected episodes of "Disney's Doug," "Disney's Recess" and "Disney's Pepper Ann" portray the experience of falling in love or being the object of a youthful "crush." Disney's Doug -- Narrated via the spoken journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, this series uses humor and fantasy in depicting the struggles of a twelve-year-old boy to define identity, develop self-confidence, resolve family and school problems and maintain friendships strained by preadolescent physical and emotional change. Series episodes promote values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. Disney's Pepper Ann -- "Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively. Disney's Recess -- "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material.

column7: ABC KIDS MOVIE MATINEE: DOUG'S QUAIL MAN MARATHON
column16: In the guise of imaginary superhero "QuailMan," Doug attempts to resolve some of his personal conflicts. With superhero canine "QuailMan" and his ally "Super Skeeter," Doug/QuailMan conquers nefarious characters and foils their selfish plots. These characters bear a striking resemblance to Guy, Roger and other mean or arrogant people in Doug's community. The story "QuailDad" is particularly nice in that QuailMan/Doug comes to realize that his father is a very talented and resourceful person -- not a klutz, as he thought, but a real-life hero.

This ABC Children's Special collects four episodes of "Disney's Recess" into a one-hour special presentation. "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material.

This ABC Children's Special collects four episodes of "Disney's Pepper Ann" into a one-hour special presentation. "Disney's Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively.

column10: Saturdays, various time periods - Oct. 3 - Dec. 26, 1998
column16: This program features Jack Hanna's worldly adventures to the remote jungles , rain forests, sea coasts and parks where kids meet new friends and learn about the importance of animals to our ecological system.

This program explores the mysteries of wild and domestic animals, introducting kids to animals of all kinds where they get to learn all about their instincts, behaviours and natural habitats. Also the show regularly offers pet tips.
This program introduces kids to topical newsworthy events and information, and features a variety of stories and people which expose kids to learn more about the world they live in.
This program entertains and teaches kids about the histories and cultures of the places they visit. It's about kids traveling the world and experiencing the excitement of "Awesome Adventures".

column7: DISNEY PRESENTS: BILL NYE THE SCIENCE GUY
column16: This program educates and informs kids in a fun and entertaining way, about fairly sophisticated scientific concepts such as buoyancy, gravity, physiology, and magnetism.

"Disney's Doug" is designed to educate and inform children who are between the ages of two and eleven years old. More specifically, the series teaches children about the fundamentals, morals and educational lessons of life.

"Popular Mechanics for Kids" gives young viewers a first hand look at how things are built and operate. The "How Team" reporters go to work sites where experts provide hands-on demonstrations on how different things work.

This program takes a look at history, art, music and science from a different angle-"up close and personal." Children go on exciting, fun-filled real life adventures. "Field Trip" encourages independent exploration with suggested reading and resources for other information.

"Click" is a teen-aged oriented educational game show. It teaches teens the importance of team work and incorporates questions from the world of entertainment and sports, as well as questions in math and science, literature, history and about current culture.

This is a game show which incorporates social and cultural issues facing today's youth and teaches them how to make proper decisions. The program provides teens with a better understanding of the factors that influence the choices that they make. It also helps them to make educated choices that will further their social and emotional development.

"Mr. Men" contains three cartoons that cleverly introduce children to a host of educationally positive ideas. It encourages children to recognize and appreciate the differences in each other, to solve problems through reasoned cooperation, to be sensitive, respect others' feelings, and a host of other important thoughts and ideas.

The Bananas, affectionately called B1 and B2, are mischievous twins who live in a brightly colored story book world with their friends, the Teddies, and a loveable rogue, Rat-In-A-Hat. They all live on Cuddles Avenue which is not just their home, but the setting for fun, games , and lots of playing tricks on one another. Each show is comprised of four segments which teach children through the interactions of the characters.

Capitalizing on the color, excitement and appeal of NASCAR racing, "Think Fast" attracts a teenage audience through use of rapid, upbeat and highly entertaining presentations of a variety of teenage issues.

Based on a series by Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark, this program features the adventures of the turtle Franklin and his friends Bear, Snail, Rabbit and Goose. The objectives of the program are to present to young viewers age-appropriate moral dilemmas addressing issues such as the meaning of right and wrong, the purposes of rules and the consequences of following or not following them, and the values inherent in telling the truth, and to teach viewers important social values such as cooperation and compromise, fairness, responsibility, self-respect and respect for others. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

From the Caldecott award winning series by Eve Titus, this program follows the escapades of Anatole the mouse, who learns to function in both the worlds of humans and mice by being clever, determined, a hard worker, a dedicated husband and father, and a problem-solver. The objectives of the program are to encourage viewers to identify and select positive alternatives when faced with personal, interpersonal and social dilemmas and to teach children that dedication and personal effort make it possible to be better family members, friends, students, workers and citizens. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

Dav Pilkey's book series, published by Scholastic, provides the basis for this program about a family of extremely naive bunnies, who use their idiosyncratic, nontraditional logic to solve problems. The objectives of the program are to introduce children to some principles of and creative approaches to problem-solving by exposing them to divergent ways of thinking, and to help them understand the importance of family relationships built on mutual respect, trust and cooperation and the value of various positive personal and social behaviors. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

In this series, four friends at Rhino Junior High use brains and brawn to deal with problems created by their nemesis Earl P. Sidebottom, who can transpose the school to faraway places and drop students into strange situations. Focusing episodically on the different members of the group, the program addresses a range of personal and social concerns faced by early adolescents, while integrating school curricular material relating to the language and creative arts, science, and history, as well as principles of critical thinking and problem solving. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

In this series, children are exposed to a variety of issues facing young teenagers as seen through the eyes of a family of birds, led by the 12-year-old Eddie Storkowitz, an aspiring filmmaker. The program focuses on coming-of-age problems related to self-esteem, peer pressure, interpersonal relationships, social roles, and civility. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

This series uses the amusing though engagingly ghoulish character the Cryptkeeper, well known to both elementary school aged and adolescent children, as a storyteller who introduces young viewers to a variety of life lessons. The objectives of the program are to assist children in learning lessons such as the importance of staying in school, the value of telling the truth and being considerate of others, and the need to exercise judgment in choosing friends, and to help viewers understand principles of self-discipline needed to solve personal problems. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

column7: MYTHIC WARRIORS: GUARDIANS OF THE LEGEND
column16: Based on the Children's Choice award-winning books by Laura Geringer, this adventure series uses a modernized Mount Olympus to introduce children to the stories of classic Greek myths and legends, related by a storyteller who emphasizes questions of right and wrong, loyalty and ethical conduct. The program teaches positive life-lessons, such as the value of personal determination, courage and compassion, while cultivating an appreciation of reading and the storytelling tradition. The program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

"Algo's FACTory" is targeted to children ages eight to fourteen. This unique educational programming concept consists of experiments and tricks, mixed with animation and humor, and developed around a central theme in each episode. The kids will perform most of the experiments under Al's (the adult character in the show)supervision, with a little help from the Bytes (a series of computer animated 'helpers'). All activities are designed to illustrate, demonstrate and teach the How's, What's and Why's. The show emphasizes that the mind is like a FACTory: to run at peak performance, you have to work it.

"Bloopy's Buddies" is a half-hour live action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children. In each episode Bloopy and his ethnically diverse cast of friends move, sing, and learn about a variety of issues regarding safety, healthy living, nutrition, creativity and music. The program's unique format features frequent movement sessions where Bloopy encourages the audience directly at home to get on their feet and join in. With both specific instruction and spontaneous action, these movement sessions inspire greater body awareness skills and the fun of fitness. Comedian Jonathan Winters offers a grandfatherly presence with important lessons on being polite, using your imagination, enjoying art, and more. "Bloopy's Buddies" has earned the approval of several prestigious advocacy groups including The Annenberg Public Policy Center, The American Academy of Pediatrics, and a Parents' Choice Gold Award.

Froozles is entertaining, enlightening and educational, which expands the cognitive and intellectual powers of the children and demonstrates how to use these principles for the well being of their emotional and social life.
Children use cognitive reasoning to measure, design and build various crafts, while emotional and social lessons are learned in the artistry of the objects.

The New Zoo Revue's musical comedy format conveys the concepts of cooperation and guidance for living in today's society. The show deals with important topics such as fear, respect, patience and sharing.
An informational and educational public affairs show which features representatives from local, regional and national groups on issues affecting viewers.
A program that aims to educate adults and children alike on the growing population of stray pets and the importance of pet care.

A locally produced show that takes viewers into the world of public education. Each program showcases teachers, parents, business people and others who are working to promote learning in California schools.
Children learn the true meaning of Christmas in this animated tale that stresses the gift of giving.
Children learn problem solving and social issues involving family and the holidays in this animated special.
It teaches, entertains, and encourages children to become comfortable with who they are today and what they can be tomorrow.
Entertaining childrens stories with an educational and informative twist.
To bring an understanding of good and bad in life and to guide children through situations they will encounter in life.

Magical World in which it brings a singer story teller, Jack Houston, he brings to life a cast of characters on a farm, the air is clean, sunshine, values are pure, music and learning are parts of each show.
It combines a variety of characters, songs, stories, animation and live action into an exciting half hour, captures childrens attention and imagination.
Two segments per show, each one tells an entire story, designed with a clear separation of entertainment, educational and informative.
A creative interesting, attractive and educational package, capitalizes on color, excitement and appeal. Each episode deals with different every day things of life.

Electric Playground is an educational show that focuses on the world of computers, computer software, computer games and the Internet. It attempts to teach children more about computers and how they are forever changing the world as we know it.

La Isla De Jordan is a non-violent, educational, half-hour television series featuring an endearing cast of zany puppet characters. The series is presented with a dialogue spoken in accent-neutral Spanish. La Isla de Jordan is designed to educate monolingual Spanish speaking and bilingual Spanish speaking children. La Isla de Jordan revolves around several characters who live and play at the Animal Trackers Zoo. By focusing on specific "real life" themes, the series strives to develop the "Emotional IQ" of children as they learn to solve problems through the experiences of the characters. In addition, they learn about animals and the environment.

A Search & Rescue 911 themed animal adventure series with an entertainimg twist of investigative and detective "super sleuthing" by a group neighborhood kids, a couple of veterinarians and a zany professor. Action and stimulating story lines combined with kids' natural love and curiosity of animals. This program promotes and teaches team work, cooperation, problem solving, knowledge of animals and positive role models.

Bookmice, Norbert, Zazi, and Leon are three fun-loving mice who secretly live behind the walls of the neighborhood public library. The mice have befriended Lee-a lonely boy who just moved into the area, Kate-the teenaged library assistant, and Alyshe and Jason-two neighborhood children. The friends, assisted by Mr. Flower, The Wizard of Wonder, and Exit the Cat, hear stories, sing songs, and watch animated films that teach children about values, constructive behavior and problem solving. The mice help the humans solve problems and encourage young viewers to explore their neighborhood library, and the world of books and reading. Bookmice is an award-winning show that has received a Gold Award at the Cairo International Film Festival fro Children and a Silver Award at the International Fils and Video Festival in New York.

Homer's Workshop is an FCC Kid-Friendly TV Show targeted at children viewers ages 6-12 years of age. The show is intended to show kids "how-to" build simple projects by hand using woodworking as the method and is similar in concept to "This Old House." The goals of the show are to teach life skills to kids as well as how to plan ahead, and how to learn by doing.

Barnyard Place relates to the lives of 3-7 year olds and it integrates the viewers in such a way that the information is the key to solving some sort of problem that one of the Barnyard place characters is having. Every show has a factual and/or emotional lesson to teach.

Provides reading readiness training, early mathematics skills, education in health, hygiene and nutrition, and provides encouragement and stimulation for academic success. Produced by CTW specifically for a Spanish-language audience.

Tigritos T.V. is comprised of a combination of live-action and animated educational segments which are designed to teach and inform children about literature, music, and science. Tigritos T.V. also teaches children the importance of family relationships. The educational portion of Tigritos T.V. on Saturday is bookended by two segments of non-core material which is used to attract young viewers to the core educational material.

column7: SAVED BY THE BELL: THE NEW CLASS (1)
column16: The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories - intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved through this series by exploring social themes through the daily school life of six teenage friends at Bayside High who help each other make the most of growing up in a complicated world. The Bayside kids give teens a useful perspective on many of the tough issues they have to face both in their peer relationships, and in personal decision-making both in and out of the classroom.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories - intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by showing how a group of teens deals with gender equality, competition, cooperation, and balancing priorities.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories - intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by showing how a group of teens deals with gender equality, competition, cooperation, and balancing priorities.

The educational objective of this program is to introduce the teen audience to the pro-social, off-court activities of basketball players and other individuals, and to individuals who have overcome various obstacles in order to achieve their goals. The program segments are based on a curriculum inspired by the U.S. Department of Education's Goals 2000, with particular focus on messages encouraging the following values: school completion, community service, cooperation, tolerance of differences,healthful practices and athletics, peaceful conflict resolutions and global awareness. These educational and informational messages are conveyed primarily through real life examples, interviews and commentary by the program's hosts.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories - intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by exploring the pressures of living in a big city environment where situations are sometimes so difficult and challenging, kids have to learn sophisticated and responsible decision-making to be safe and stay focused. The series follows the encounters and problem-solving of two young men through an eventful school year at Manhattan High and shows teens how to work with their principal, family and friends to be successful.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational messsage to the audience which may fall into one or more categories -- intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved through this series by exploring socio-emotional themes of identity, self-worth, social reciprocity, service to others and acceptance of differences. Through the characters in the show, our audience will see examples of different approaches to resolving problems caused by these issues.

A trio of live-action teen angels have taken on the task of broadcasting children's programs hoping to inspire and inform children through their own issues which correspond to the many moral lessons depicted through the long-form programs they broadcast. The long-form programs (as further described below) are informational and educational for children ages 5-9. ZAK TALES - Zak is the Mayor of Fun Town. The costumed Zak offers children solutions to the universal problems associated with growing up by drawing examples from classic children's literature and with characters in similar plights, such as Robinson Crusoe, Tom Thumb and Sinbad. Zak and his sidekick, Kilroy, lead their viewers on adventures filled with exciting stories, jokes, sing-alongs and even a little rap poetry. THE SYLVANIAN FAMILIES - This animated series of bears, rabbits, racoons, mice, beavers and foxes who live in the Sylvanian forest show that they have troubles like everyone else: fires, floods and storms. The villain Packbat and his sidekick, Gatorpossum, add to their troubles. The Sylvanian Families band together to solve every problem. Illustrating what a family is all about and allowing the audience to become a part of the family through their adventures. Some themes include pulling togehter, sharing resources and doing the right thing. THE TOOTHBRUSH FAMILY - The animated characters who live in the bathroom explore their environment on exciting adventures. The two brand new toothbrushes, Molly & Max, work with their friends, Flash, Fluoride & Susie Sponge, to become responsible toothbrushes, relating to children on their way to becoming responsible grown-ups. GET ALONG GANG - In Green Meadows, there lives a merry group of animated animal friends, The Get Along Gang, who are always ready to lend a helping hand in their own caring and clever way. They travel through the countryside in the Clubhouse Caboose, sharing adventures and stories presenting themes illustrating respect, trust, teamwork, helping others in need and responsibility. FOR DECEMBER 5, 1998, ONLY, THE ABOVE-LONG FORM PROGRAMMING WAS REPLACED BY THE FOLLOWING: SWISS FAMILY ROBINSON - The classic literary tale comes to life in this complelling live-action series. The show is shot on Fiji in the South Pacific and chronicles the story of the loving, closely-knit Robinson family as they face day-to-day struggles of being shipwrecked on a deserted island, far from home. Whether they are battling pirates, facing personal family tragedy or surviving Mother Nature, the Swiss Family Robinson demonstrates that family unity, honesty and goodness can triumph in the end. INQUIRING MINDS - An engaging magazine-format show designed to investigate many of the questions about everyday life, such as: why is the ocean salty, why chili peppers are hot and why skin itches. Some things not found in everyday life are also discussed, such as: how one can really walk on hot coals. By adding vivid demonstrations, fun sound effects, real photos, contemporary music and some clever graphics, the answers to some of life's most puzzling questions are revealed. It helps children learn how to think things through and how science fits into everyday life. SUPER MARIO BROTHERS - This animated series based on the characters from the Nintendo video game illustrates good versus evil. King Koopa and his daughter Kootie Pie battle to control the world as the Mario Brothers (Mario and Luigi), the Princess and Toad work to save the day. The show demonstrates working together, the bad side of greed and how learning new things will benefit you.

The trio of live-action angels continue with their task of broadcasting children's programs in hope of inspiring and informing children. We see them behind the scenes in the Cloud 9 studio where they work together to run the station while dealing with their own personal problems and work dilemmas that correspond to the many moral lessons depicted in the programs they broadcast. Each long-form segement serves to highlight and reinforce the educational and moral elements of the series. Overall themes include overcoming fears, being responsible, dealing with jealousy, respecting others, handling anger, learning to trust, resolving conflict, having a good attitude and self-esteem, using teamwork and being cooperative, being prepared, helping others, discouraging cheating and lying and promoting hard work and dedication. The long-form segments are targeted to children 6-10 and descriptions of these segments follow: SWISS FAMILY ROBINSON - The classic literary tale comes to life in this complelling live-action series. The show is shot on Fiji in the South Pacific and chronicles the story of the loving, closely-knit Robinson family as they face day-to-day struggles of being shipwrecked on a deserted island, far from home. Whether they are battling pirates, facing personal family tragedy or surviving Mother Nature, the Swiss Family Robinson demonstrates that family unity, honesty and goodness can triumph in the end. INQUIRING MINDS - An engaging magazine-format show designed to investigate many of the questions about everyday life, such as: why is the ocean salty, why chili peppers are hot and why skin itches. Some things not found in everyday life are also discussed, such as: how one can really walk on hot coals. By adding vivid demonstrations, fun sound effects, real photos, contemporary music and some clever graphics, the answers to some of life's most puzzling questions are revealed. It helps children learn how to think things through and how science fits into everyday life. HURRICANES - The excitement of chapionship soccer comes to life, with all the behind-the-scenes, off-the-field drama and action this animated series can bring. The show features a cast of international soccer players as members of the Hurricanes, who travel to exotic locales around the world. Thanks to an unexpected inheritance, an American teenager, Amanda, becomes the new owner of the team. Set on the island of Hipaniola, the characters include the diverse, international personalities who make up the team, an eccentric coach, his son, the physician and one unruly mascot. The series teaches teamwork, competition, winning and losing, and how to handle the moments of glory and defeat. US SPACE FORCE - The race for knowledge and the fight to defend freedom are at the heart of the courageous adventure of Starcom. Starcom, along with Starbase Command, Airwing and the Astro Marines are the premiere peacekeeping force in the growing planetary commuity. The heroes are a team of the best and brightest, making full use of their ultra-sophisticated vehicles and state-of-the-art technology to confront the sinister Emperor Dark. This animated show of heros, exploration, adventure and excitement set against the backdrop of colonization of the Solar System shows the cooperative efforts to keep the peace. Similarities can be drawn to the growing, changing children's environment.

This program is educational and intended to inform children 16 years of age and under. It airs at 7am Mondays through Saturdays, 30 minutes in length. This series is designed to enlighten chiildren about animals and the environment. Children also learn valuable everyday life lessons through the actions and interactions of the characters.

Educational and Informational Objective: This program combines live action with animation and music to provide education and instruction in a variety of areas of value to children in this age group (scholastic as well as practical skills). This program is in Korean. Based on content, airtime and length, the program meets points 1-4. It is included in this form 398 to meet point 5 and is reported to program guide publishers as educational to meet point 6.

Educational and informational objective: This program teaches moral and behavioral lessons in the form of traditional Chinese tales and fables produced as colorful costume dramas. The show is in Mandarin with Chinese subtitles that make it accessible to Cantonese speaking and hearing impaired viewers. Based on content, airtime and length, the program meets points 1-4. It is included in this form 398 to meet point 5, and is reported to program guide publishers as educational to meet point 6.

This program is in Mandarin with Chinese subtitling that also makes it accessible to Cantonese-speaking and hearing-impaired viewers. The program features a young energetic hostess who with her chimpanzee puppet sidekick and the assistance of experts in various fields, teaches children about a wide variety of subjects by utilizing on-site, hands-on experience.
GOSPEL BILL educates and informs children between the ages of 6 - 12 by teaching positive social skills and self awareness based on Biblical principles.
JANICE'S ATTIC educates and informs children between the ages of 4 - 8 about nature, personal health and the value of positive character qualities.
KIDS AGAINST CRIME educates and informs children between the ages of 5 - 12 by exploring the real-life crimes committed against and by youth and the penalities for those who commit these crimes.
"Kids Like You" educates and informs children between the ages of 6-12 by presenting challenging situations with solutions that develop character.
COLBY'S CLUBHOUSE educates and informs children between the ages of 6 - 12 about how to successfully deal with everday situations and challenges using the principles of the Bible.

"Just the Facts" educates and informs children between the ages of 10-16 by teaching critical thinking and problem solving skills based on Bible principles to help adolescents deal with issues that affect them.
KIDS CLUB educates and informs children between the ages of 3 - 9 about history through the Bible as well as teaching children about safety and offering exercise instructions.
FAITHVILLE educates and informs children between the ages of 4 - 16 about the value of team work and the inportance of the individual within the community.
"Kids on the Move" educates and informs children between teh ages of 6-12 about historical information using Bible questions in a game show.

The program seeks to increase young viewer's awareness and appreciation for history and historical references, and to enhance viewer's knowledge and understanding of different ethnic, religious, cultural, geographical and gender based groups through history and modern time to promote tolerance and diversity. To help viewers learn to exercise logic, judgement and analytical skills.

The program seeks to increase young viewer's awareness and appreciation for history and historical references, and to enhance viewer's knowledge and understanding of different ethnic, religious, cultural, geograpical and gender based groups through history and modern times to promote tolerance and diversity. To help viewers learn to exercise logic, judgement and analytical skills.
Told through a teenager's point of view, story lines illustrating issues of peer pressure, self esteem, tolerance and acceptance blend humor and adventure with positive social messages.
Explains the complexities of the world to young children, focusing on dealing with the challenges of growing up and teaching children about the importance of family, friends and values.
Offers children the opportunity to explore issues and scenarios common to growing up yet perplexing to them, such as how to cope with family and friends as part of this process.

Explores science through an animated journey aboard a magically transformed school bus to destinations such as the center of the earth, inside the human body, outer space, remote ecological environments, inside a molecule and inside a plant.
Explains the complexities of the world to young children, focusing on dealing with the challenges of growing up and teaching children about the importance of family, friends and values.

Oye Arnold presents a fresh new look at life in a big city from a child's point of view. The program focuses on Arnold, the principal character and his friendship as they learn to deal with challenges, fears, temptations and responsability.

Lift-Off is a story book program. Each program presents a group of characters in a different adventure. Through these stories and their protagonist, children discover that they are able to face certain situations and resolve their daily problems. Each day a story teaches a different lesson regarding the commmunity, friendship relationships, and experience they will encounter in the future. Children also learn the meaning of hope and perserverance.

Is an interactive pre-school program, which teaches children how to use the basic tools for critical thinking and reasoning, before going to school for the first time. Clues are given through-out the program by Steve, the principal host and his dog Blue.

CHIQUITRAN IS BASED ON THE CONCEPT OF TEACHING ENTERTAINMENT. EACH PROGRAM DEALS WITH A SPECIIFIC TOPIC (SUCH AS RECYCLING) OR A CULTURE (SUCH AS THE AZTECS). CHIQUITRAN ALSO INCLUDES VISITS TO THE MUSEUM OR ZOO, BOOK READING AND A CHILDREN'S NEWSCAST WITH INTERVIEWS AND ARTISTS, SPORTS FIGURES, ETC. CHIQUITRAN IS A RESULT OF KWHY'S COMMITMENT TO L.A.'S HISPANIC CHILDREN. THIS PROGRAM AIRS FREE FROM INTERRUPTIONS.

DESAFIO ACADEMICO MOTIVATES STUDENTS TO STUDY PRIMARY SUBJECTS SUCH AS MATHEMATICS, SCIENCE, HISTORY, GEOGRAPHY, AND LANGUAGE SKILLS WITHIN A FUN, TEAM BUILDING, AND COMPETITIVE ENVIRONMENT. SPANISH SPEAKING HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ARE CHALLENGED TO MEET HIGH SCHOOL EQUIVALANCY STANDARDS BY DEMONSTRATING THEIR PROFICIENCY IN THREE SUBJECTS.

BOOKMICE IS A CHILDREN'S SERIES ATTENTIVE TO THE CREATIVE LEARNING PROCESS THROUGH STORIES, MUSIC, HUMOR, AND IMAGINATION. SET WITHIN A NEIGHBORHOOD LIBRARY, BOOKMICE TEACHES LOVE OF READING, SOCIAL VALUES, HELPING OTHERS, THE IMPORTANCE OF HONESTY, PROBLEM SOLVING, AND OVERCOMING FEARS.
This educational half-hour magazine show for children ages 5-12 features guest hosts who introduce studio, puppet and animated segments. Human relations, language skills and science are taught.

This award-winning series of half-hour educational programs for children ages 4-9 uses a musical comedy format to convey the concepts of cooperation and to encourage children to be caring and constructive citizens. The show’s awards include endorsements by the NEA and by the National School Boards Association; a Four-Star Rating from the National PTA Review Board; and a Certificate of Quality from the California State PTA.

An award-winning educational half-hour program for children ages 5-8 which combines puppetry, live action, animation and storytelling to stimulate interest in books and reading. Bookmice was replaced by Jack Houston's Imagineland at the 8 a.m. time slot.

This Telly award-winning educational half-hour program for children ages 4-9, aired on numerous PBS stations in all major markets, features singer-storyteller Jack Houston and the characters who live on his farm. Through live action and puppetry, Mr. Houston and his animal friends deal with a wide spectrum of life experiences. Children learn valuable life lessons: from the importance of reading to the importance of friends and everything in between. The 8:30 a.m. time slot for this program was replaced by The Reppies.

This series of half-hour educational programs for children ages 2-8 teaches virtues and values with sensitivity, humor and music through the characters of a live action musical group called The Reppies. Children gain insight into their lives at school, as well as with friends, family and the world around them by learning through The Reppies' own experiences.

This half-hour award-winning educational series is designed to foster music appreciation in youngsters ages 6-12. The primary focus of each program is to impart knowledge about a particular musical instrument or style of music. This show was produced at and aired on several PBS stations in the United States.

This half-hour program educates and informs children ages 13-16 about the environment and various outdoor activities they can enjoy with family and friends. Guests and experts share their knowledge to help children participate safely in the activities featured on the show.

The Reppies, a live action musical group, plan a Christmas celebration, complete with carols, trees, sleigh bells and snow. Their friends, Katie and Buster, explain that they would love it if the holidays they observe with their families could be represented in the concert. The Reppies' curiosity about those holidays leads to entertaining lessons on Kwanzaa and Hanukkah; the Christmas special becomes a musical, magical Holiday special enjoyed by everyone
Each show is a problem solving adventure with the audience playing along. Children learn about Science, Math and Music with a live cast.
Children are introduced to a fun new way to be entertained and educated while they enjoy the experience of the great outdoors. Children learn safty tips,environmental issues and equipment needs.
Each episode will explore a specific "kid Issue." Doug's fantasies explore the best and worst possibilities inherent in any given situation.
Children see how different things are made such as planes, toy trains, bicycles, washing machine, computer, automobiles, steel, pencils and etc...
This is designed to guide young people into making educated choices for their lives by introducing the worlds most colorful and challenging careers.
Teaches children about animals and their environment.
